title: Rashi on Taanit
text: Mishnah: From when do we mention the power of rain?  - that we say he causes the wind to blow and the rain to fall and the Gemara explains the reason why its called power of rain because he causes it fall with power like it says he made the big

And his bed was placed, etc.: The legs of his bed were placed in buckets full of water so that ants should not climb onto him via the legs of the bed. As he was an amputee; and if they would climb upon him, he would not be able to take them with his hands and throw them [off].
That occurred to him: Everything that happened to him, even the bad.
He slept in a certain lodging: He lodged one night at that inn.
To his sifta: His chest.
All of them: The enemies of the Jews (a euphemism for the Jews).
As one of them: As one of the ministers of Caesar.
Is from the earth of Avraham: [From] when he fought with the kings.
Gilei: Straw.
They slept: They lodged at the inn.
Abba Umna: Bloodletter.
Greetings from the Firmament: A Divine Voice would say to him, "Peace unto you."
When he would perform a matter: When he was letting blood from people.
And from the women by themselves: For modesty.
That had a horn: Ventose. As the horn with which he let blood was fixed in it. And he would clothe the women with it.
And he was not embarrassed: Since after he struck (let the blood), he did not know who put coins (in its slit) and who did not put [them there].
Health your spirit: Heal yourself.
To investigate him: To investigate him by his deeds.
He spread out mats (bistarki) for them: He folded wool ornaments under them - traped in [Old French] - to sleep in them.
In the morning, they rolled them up: The rabbis [rolled up] Abba the Bloodletter's mats and brought them to the marketplace to sell them.

They said to him, to Abba the Bloodletter, "Let the Master appraise them and give us their value." And they were examining him, whether he would suspect them as robbers, or whether he would appraise [the mats for] less than their value.
What did you suspect us of when we took them.
And it embarrassed you to tell me the matter immediately, to give them [to you]. And that is why you came to sleep with me, to do all of this.
Let the Master take them: As we only wanted to test you.
Ugah: A circular line; like a cake, which is round.
In the manner that Habakkuk did: As is explained in the Targum on Habakkuk on, "I will stand upon my watch" - he made a type of prison and sat [there].
We have seen you, but we shall not die: "We have seen you, but we shall not die," is as a statement: Take efforts that we shall not die from hunger due to the stoppage of the rain.
A bull of hodaah: Upon which to confess [sins]. He leaned upon it; and they brought peace-offerings. And Choni [lived] at the time of the Temple.
Truffles and mushrooms: Boleiz, in [Old French]. As they come out from the dampness of the rain, and they knew that it was rains of blessing.
If you were not Choni and a great man.
For ostracism: As we ostracize [somone] on account of the honor of the master. And he cast [irreverent] statements and said, "I did not ask for this."
For were these years like the years of Elijah: [A time of] a decree on the stoppage of the rain.
And the key for rain was in Elijah’s hands: We teach [this version of the text].

Wouldn’t the name of Heaven have been desecrated: By way of a question. As Eliyahu had sworn (I Kings 17:1), "As the Lord lives [...], there will be no dew or rain except by my word"; and you swore that you would not move until rain falls.
Wouldn’t the name of Heaven have been desecrated: As one or the other would come to a vain oath.
Mitchateh (Nag): It is an expression of sin; meaning that he was continuing to sin.
The Chamber of the Hewn Stone:: The Sanhedrin.
A generation that was in darkness due to great pain. As there was no rainfall.
You saved through your prayer from death. As you brought them plenty.
Of that righteous man - Choni HaMe’aggel - he was distressed over this verse.
A song of Ascents: It is an expression of ascending.
We were like those who dream: The Babylonian exile, which was seventy years, was like a dream.
Seventy years in a dream: By way of a question: Is there someone who sleeps seventy years in his dream; and is there any person who sleeps seventy years at one time?
Until seventy years [until] it produces fruit for the first time.
We teach [the following version]: I found a world full of carob trees. Just as my ancestors planted for me, I too am planting for my descendants.
He sat [meaning,] Choni HaMe'aggel, and he ate bread.
A cliff formed around him: A boulder arose around him.
And he was concealed from sight: So they did not find him there.
Several herds: The offspring of offspring. It was pregnant with a male, and during those years that he slept, it also mated with it and they were born.
He said to them: He asked them, "Is the son of Choni HaMe’aggel alive?"

These discussions are enlightening us: This discussion is as illuminated as if he had learned it in the lifetime of Choni HaMe’aggel, who would break it apart for us and illuminate it very well for us.

Either friendship or death: And we do not teach [the version], "like the friends of Iyov," here; but rather [only] in Bava Batra (16b), concerning the story of Iyov. If the friends of a person do not honor him as at first, it is better to him that he should die. "Alternatively, certain hooligans," is not written in our books (in Taanit 23b:7)>
Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa: He was a Tanna (an early Talmudic teacher from the period before the Mishnah was composed).
The entire world is suffering: Since they are requesting water for their fields.
Is comfortable: Since I am sitting in my house and I do not need rain, as I do not have fields.

What effect does the prayer of the High Priest have when the High Priest would recite the brief prayer on Yom Kippur - as he would say, "And let not the prayer of travelers enter Your presence." For Rabbi Chanina ben Dosa would negate the prayer of the High Priest. As the Holy One, blessed be He, would listen to [Rabbi Chanina's] prayer, in spite of it, and stop the rain.
Shechunah: Hot; similarly, Yonatan ben Uziel translates (Isaiah 44:16), "I am warm, I can feel the fire," (in the Targum, as), shachenit.
If it will be hot, may it be rainy: If it is hot, the land requires much rain frequently.
A Divine Voice emerges and says, "The entire world": And we do not teach [the version, "emerges] from Mount Chorev."
A kav of carobs, from Shabbat eve to Shabbat eve: He would be sustained the whole week with that. He was lacking bread, so he would suffice with carobs.
Aktarta: Something that brings up smoke like the smoke of a furnace.
Due to embarrassment: Since her neighbors were baking dough to honor the Shabbat, whereas she was not doing anything.
Agana: A kneading basin.
Masa: A shovel with which we remove the bread. A mardeh is a pele in [Old French]; and a mardeh and a masa are one thing.

It was taught, "She too had entered to bring a mardeh": That is a pele in [Old French. It is called this,] since we rodeh (remove) the bread form the oven with it. As she did not borrow [but rather already had one], since she was accustomed to miracles.
She saw: His wife [saw] in a dream.
It does not take [something back] after it gives.
Any place, we teach, bei shimshei (twilight), it is about Shabbat eve. I have not heard the reason.
For a vessel of vinegar: For a vessel that has the vinegar in it. So I placed the vinegar into the lamp and the lamp became extinguished.

Until they brought from it fire for havdalah: He lit another light from it, from which to benefit, and extinguished the lamp of the miracle story - like Rav Yehudah did (Taanit 24b) with the sand that became fine flour.
They are causing damage: [Our] fields.
Bears and wolves in the fields.
But the ceiling did not reach: The beams did not reach from one wall to [the other] wall.
If so (ikku), may your beams reach: May the beams stretch.
They were segments: The beams were made of segments. Through the occurrence of the miracle, small pieces became attached along their length.

When the gates close -- The Jerusalem Talmud, tractate Berachot, in the chapter [beginning with] "the morning prayer", defines when the "closing" occurs. One opinion is that it refers to the gates of the temple, and one opinion is that it refers to the gates of heaven, which are closed close to evening at the completion of prayers.  And it was customary to add the Neilah prayer on all public fast days the same way we do on Yom Kippur.
This is the giving of the Torah- The Day of Atonement, when the second Tablets were given
Whoever enters Adar: Days of miracles - these were for the Jews - Purim and Pesach

1 "[the day] on which the deaths ceased in the desert" - As it was taught in a braita, all 40 years that they were in the desert, every Erev Tisha B’av, the proclaimer would go out and say: let each individual go out and dig [his grave]. And every single person would go out and dig for themselves a grave, and sleep in it, in case they would die before they had dug. And the next day, the proclaimer would go out and proclaim: let the living separate themselves from the dead. And every one who had the soul of life would rise and go out [of his grave]. And every year they would do this. And in the 40th year, they did it, and the next morning everyone stood up alive. And when they saw this, they were astonished, and they said, ‘perhaps we made a mistake in calculating the month [and it is not yet Tisha B’Av].’ They returned and slept in their graves each night until the 15th, and since they saw that the moon was full on Tu [B’av] and no one had died among them, they knew that the calculation of the month was in line, and that the 40 years of the decree had been completed, they established that day as a Yom Tov.
